en.label: Calendar of Harptos (Forgotten Realms)
en.description: The standard calendar of Faer√ªn, featuring twelve 30-day months interspersed with festival days that fall outside the normal monthly structure. Used throughout the Forgotten Realms in D&D campaigns.

months.name: Hammer
months.description: The deepest winter month, named for the need to break ice for water. A time of cold, darkness, and huddled warmth around hearth fires.

months.name: Alturiak
months.description: The Claw of Winter. Storms rage and travel becomes treacherous. Also called 'The Claws of the Cold'.

months.name: Ches
months.description: The Claw of the Sunsets. Late winter begins to break, but cold snaps still threaten. The month of planning for spring.

months.name: Tarsakh
months.description: The Claw of the Storms. Spring rains and winds arrive with violent storms. Roads become muddy and travel difficult.

months.name: Mirtul
months.description: The Melting. Late spring brings warmth and the final melting of winter snow. Planting season begins in earnest.

months.name: Kythorn
months.description: The Time of Flowers. Early summer brings blooming flowers and mild weather. A popular time for weddings and festivals.

months.name: Flamerule
months.description: Summertide. The height of summer with sweltering heat. Named for the oppressive temperatures that rule this month.

months.name: Eleasis
months.description: Highsun. The hottest month of the year. Crops grow rapidly but water becomes precious. Also called 'The Deep Summer'.

months.name: Eleint
months.description: The Fading. Early autumn brings cooler weather and the beginning of harvest season. Leaves start to change color.

months.name: Marpenoth
months.description: Leaffall. Mid-autumn brings falling leaves and the main harvest. A time of preparation for the coming winter.

months.name: Uktar
months.description: The Rotting. Late autumn brings decay and the first frosts. The final preparations for winter are completed.

months.name: Nightal
months.description: The Drawing Down. Early winter brings short days and long nights. The year draws to its close in cold and darkness.

weekdays.name: 1st
weekdays.description: First day of the tenday, often used for planning and new endeavors

weekdays.name: 2nd
weekdays.description: Second day of the tenday, a common day for beginning journeys

weekdays.name: 3rd
weekdays.description: Third day of the tenday, often devoted to crafts and trade

weekdays.name: 4th
weekdays.description: Fourth day of the tenday, a day for business and commerce

weekdays.name: 5th
weekdays.description: Fifth day of the tenday, the middle day often used for important meetings

weekdays.name: 6th
weekdays.description: Sixth day of the tenday, commonly a day for visiting and socializing

weekdays.name: 7th
weekdays.description: Seventh day of the tenday, often devoted to learning and study

weekdays.name: 8th
weekdays.description: Eighth day of the tenday, a day for worship and religious observances

weekdays.name: 9th
weekdays.description: Ninth day of the tenday, commonly used for festivals and celebrations

weekdays.name: 10th
weekdays.description: Tenth day of the tenday, the final day often used for rest and reflection

intercalary.name: Midwinter
intercalary.description: Also known as Deadwinter Day. A solemn festival marking the midpoint of winter, when the year is symbolically reborn. A time for remembering the dead and making resolutions.

intercalary.name: Greengrass
intercalary.description: A festival welcoming the first day of spring. Communities gather to celebrate renewal, growth, and the end of winter's grip. Often includes dancing around maypoles.

intercalary.name: Midsummer
intercalary.description: A festival celebrating love, music, and the peak of summer. The longest day of the year is marked with feasts, music, dancing, and romantic pursuits.

intercalary.name: Shieldmeet
intercalary.description: Occurs only once every four years, the day after Midsummer. A grand festival of unity, oaths, and great celebrations. Political alliances are often forged on this day.

intercalary.name: Higharvestide
intercalary.description: A festival celebrating the autumn harvest. Communities gather to give thanks for the year's bounty and prepare for winter. Markets overflow with the season's produce.

intercalary.name: Feast of the Moon
intercalary.description: A festival honoring the dead and ancestors. The boundaries between life and death are thinnest on this night. Stories of heroes and ancestors are shared around fires.
